content.text: Bash chmod Command - Change File Permissions
The chmod command is used to change the file permissions in Unix-like operating systems.
content.html: The chmod command is used to change the file permissions in Unix-like operating systems.

content.text: It allows you to set who can read, write, or execute a file.
content.html: It allows you to set who can read, write, or execute a file.

content.text: The basic syntax of the chmod command is:
content.html: The basic syntax of the chmod command is:

content.code_html: chmod [options] mode[,mode] file1 [file2 ...]

content.text: The chmod command has several options to customize its behavior:
content.html: The chmod command has several options to customize its behavior:

content.text: The -R option allows you to change permissions for files and directories recursively.
content.html: The -R option allows you to change permissions for files and directories recursively.

content.text: This is useful when you want to apply the same permissions to all files and subdirectories within a directory.
content.html: This is useful when you want to apply the same permissions to all files and subdirectories within a directory.

content.code:
chmod
-R
755
/path/to/directory
changed permissions of 'file1' to 0755
changed permissions of 'file2' to 0755
content.code_html:
chmod -R 755 /path/to/directory
changed permissions of 'file1' to 0755
changed permissions of 'file2' to 0755

content.text: The -v option provides verbose output, showing a diagnostic message for each file processed by the command.
content.html: The -v option provides verbose output, showing a diagnostic message for each file processed by the command.

content.code:
chmod
-v
644
file.txt
mode of 'file.txt' changed from 0644 (rw-r--r--) to 0644 (rw-r--r--)
content.code_html:
chmod -v 644 file.txt
mode of 'file.txt' changed from 0644 (rw-r--r--) to 0644 (rw-r--r--)

content.html: The chmod command is commonly used to:
